message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of lethargy, poor muscle tone, and feeding difficulty with occasional regurgitation that recently turned into projectile vomiting suggest a possible disorder in organic acid metabolism. Elevated levels of ketone bodies, glycine, and methylmalonic acid further suggest a deficiency in the enzyme propionyl-CoA carboxylase, which converts propionyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA. Therefore, the deficient enzyme catalyzes the reaction of converting propionyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA. The correct answer is (B).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, physical examination findings, and laboratory results suggest the child has a urea cycle disorder, specifically a deficiency in ornithine transcarbamylase, which catalyzes the reaction between carbamoyl phosphate and ornithine to produce citrulline and CoA. Therefore, the deficient enzyme produces Succinyl-CoA (B).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest organic acidemia, particularly propionic acidemia. The deficient enzyme is propionyl-CoA carboxylase, which catalyzes the conversion of propionyl-CoA to methylmalonyl-CoA. Therefore, the answer is (C), methylmalonyl-CoA.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory results suggest a diagnosis of propionic acidemia, which is a deficiency of the enzyme propionyl-CoA carboxylase. This enzyme catalyzes the conversion of propionyl-CoA to methylmalonyl-CoA, making option (C) the correct answer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory test results suggest a diagnosis of propionic acidemia, an enzyme deficiency that impairs the breakdown of certain amino acids and fatty acids. The deficient enzyme is propionyl-CoA carboxylase, which catalyzes the conversion of propionyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA. Therefore, the product of the reaction catalyzed by the deficient enzyme is (B) Succinyl-CoA.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory results suggest a possible diagnosis of propionic acidemia, which is caused by deficiency of propionyl-CoA carboxylase enzyme. The deficient enzyme catalyzes the conversion of propionyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA, making (B) Succinyl-CoA the correct answer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest the patient has a metabolic disorder, specifically a deficiency in one of the enzymes involved in the urea cycle, which results in elevated levels of ketone bodies, glycine, and methylmalonic acid, and normal levels of citrulline. The deficient enzyme catalyzes the conversion of succinyl-CoA to succinate, so the correct answer is (B) Succinyl-CoA.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Elevated levels of ketone bodies, glycine, and methylmalonic acid suggest a deficiency in methylmalonyl-CoA mutase, which is responsible for the conversion of methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA. Therefore, the product of the reaction catalyzed by the deficient enzyme in this patient is (C) Methylmalonyl-CoA.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory test results suggest that the patient has propionic acidemia, an inherited disorder of metabolism. The deficient enzyme is propionyl-CoA carboxylase, which catalyzes the reaction of propionyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA. Therefore, the correct answer is (B) Succinyl-CoA.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, laboratory findings, and elevated levels of methylmalonic acid suggest a diagnosis of methylmalonic acidemia. This is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme methylmalonyl-CoA mutase, which catalyzes the conversion of methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA. Therefore, the answer is (B) succinyl-CoA.
